item.title: What is PMDK (Persistent Memory Development Kit)?
item.description: Answer The Persistent Memory Development Kit (PMDK), formerly known as the Non-Volatile Memory Library (NVML), is a collection of libraries and tools designed to support development of persistent-memory-aware applications. The open source PMDK project currently supports ten libraries, which are targeted at various use cases for persistent memory with language support for C, C++, Java*, and Python*. The PMDK also includes tools like the pmemcheck plug-in for the open source toolset, valgrind, and an increasing body of documentation, code examples, tutorials, and blog entries.

item.title: What programming languages does PMDK (Persistent Memory Development Kit) support?
item.description: Answer The Persistent Memory Development Kit (PMDK) core libraries provide C APIs. Libraries such as libpmemobj provide C++ APIs. Higher level libraries such as libpmemkv, a key-value store for persistent memory, support C, C++, Javascript, Java, Ruby, and Python.

item.title: Why use PMDK (Persistent Memory Development Kit)?
item.description: Answer The Persistent Memory Development Kit (PMDK) is designed to solve persistent memory challenges and facilitate the adoption of persistent memory programming. It offers developers well-tested, production-ready libraries and tools in a comprehensive implementation of the Storage Networking Industry Association Non-Volatile Memory (SNIA NVM) programming model.
